task.title: Task entities
task.shortdesc: Entities are provided to be reused in the DITA files for the documentation. While this file must be translated, it must not be included in the information center or the TOC for any deliverable.

prereq.p: If necessary, complete the following prerequisites before you begin the task.

ul.li: To run a script after an alert is triggered, create the script before the alert.Â

If you want to use Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) traps, events, or email as an alert notification, you must first configure these settings by using the web-based GUI. In the menu bar of the web-based GUI, click SettingsAlert Notifications.

taskbody.context: If necessary, configure alert notification settings before you begin the task.

step.cmd: In the Description field, type a brief description of the job.
In the Triggering-Condition area, specify the event that triggers the alert:

substep.cmd: In the Condition field, select the triggering condition.
In the Value field, type a numeric value.
substep.info: Depending on the triggering condition that you selected, this field might be unavailable.

In the Triggering Condition pane, specify the event that triggers the alert:

substep.cmd: In the Condition field, select the triggering condition.
substep.info: See for a list of triggering conditions that are available for each alert type.

substep.cmd: If you selected a performance threshold, specify the thresholds:

ol.li: In the Critical Stress field, type the upper-threshold boundary. When this boundary is exceeded, a critical condition is recognized.
In the Warning Stress field, type the upper-threshold boundary. When this boundary is exceeded, a warning condition is recognized.
In the Warning Idle field, type the lower-threshold boundary. When the value falls under this boundary, a warning condition is recognized.
In the Critical Idle field, type the lower-threshold boundary. When the value falls under this boundary, a critical condition is recognized.

step.cmd: In the Triggering Condition area, specify the event that triggers the alert:

substep.cmd: In the Rdbms Type field, select the type of database application.
substep.info: You can choose All Rdbms, Oracle, SQL\Server, Sybase, or UDB.

substep.cmd: In the Condition field, select the triggering condition.
In the Value field, type a numeric value.
substep.info: Depending on the triggering condition that you selected, this field might be unavailable.

substep.cmd: In the Triggering Condition area, the only condition is File Archive/Backup Failed. This condition indicates that an alert is triggered automatically if the archive or backup fails to run.
In the Triggered Actions area, select the actions that occur as a result of the triggering condition You can choose from the following actions:

dlentry.dd: An SNMP trap is sent to any NMS, console, or terminal when the condition occurs.

A event is sent when the condition occurs. The administrator can write correlation and automation rules to analyze events according to the event definitions specified in the tivoliSRM.baroc file (provided with the product). It also performs responses such as sending further notification, creating or updating trouble tickets, or running programs.
The alert is sent to an user. The user receives the alert upon logging in to . In the Login ID field, type the user ID.
The ID of the user who receives alert notification upon logging on to the system.
The ID of the user who receives alert notification upon logging on to the system.
The type of event that is recorded to the OS log.
The location where the UNIX Syslog is sent. You can select User or Local.
The level of UNIX Syslog event. You can select Informational, Notice, Warning, Error, Critical, or Alert.

A script is run when the condition occurs. Click Define to specify the script that is run when the triggering condition occurs. The parameters that are listed in the Specify Script window are passed to the script when the alert is triggered.
An email is sent. Click Add or Delete to edit the list of email addresses to which an email is sent. Click Edit email to change the actual email message.

step.cmd: In the How often to run area, schedule how often you want the quota to be checked You can choose from the following actions:

dlentry.dd: Check the quota immediately.

Check the quota one time at a specified time and date. You can use the drop-down lists to specify the month, day year, and the hour, minute, and AM/PM.The framework that starts the jobs finds all jobs in an interval between one minute to the scheduled time and the scheduled start time. This action ensures that if many jobs are planned to run at a certain time, they will not all start after the scheduled start time.

Check the quota repeatedly according to a schedule you specify. You can:
Use the drop-down lists to specify the month, day year, and the hour, minute, and AM/PM when the job is to begin running.
Indicate how often the job is to run. You can use the drop-down lists to specify the number of minutes, hours, days, weeks, or months.
Indicate which days on which run the job. A check mark is displayed next to the days you select.

step.cmd: In the How to Handle Time Zones area, indicate the time zone to be used when you schedule and run the policy.
step.stepxmp: For example, if you selected to run the job at 9:00 AM, you can use the fields to run it at these times.

substep.cmd: 9:00 AM of the time zone where the Data server is located
9:00 AM of a specific time zone, such as 9:00 AM CST or 9:00 GMT.
substep.stepxmp: For example, if you select 9:00 AM CST, the job runs at 7:00 AM on an agent that is in the PST time zone.

dlentry.dt: Use the timezone that the server runs in
dlentry.dd: Select this option to use the time zone where the Data server is located.
Select this option to indicate a specific time zone for when to run the job. When you select this option, a drop-down list is activated. Select the timezone from this drop-down list.

step.cmd: In the Triggering Condition area, specify the event that triggers the alert:

substep.cmd: In the Condition field, the default setting is User Consumes More Than n, where n represents a value that you define in the Value field. No other conditions are available.

In the Value field, type a numeric value that represents the storage usage limit for the quota. If the storage entities selected for the quota (for example, users and user groups) exceed this limit, the quota is triggered.
In the Value Units field, select the unit of measurement. kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes.

step.cmd: In the Triggering Condition area, specify the event that triggers the alert:

substep.cmd: In the Condition field, the default setting is User Consumes More Than n, where n represents a value that you define in the Value field. No other conditions are available.

In the Value field, enter the value that represents the percentage of a NetApp's hard limit at which the alert is triggered. The hard limit represents the most amount of space a user or directory (Qtree) can consume on a NAS filer.
substep.stepxmp: For example, the hard limit that is defined within a NetApp Quota for a user group is 150 MB, and you enter 90 in the Value field. The Data Manager quota reports a violation when that user group consumes 135 or more megabytes.

substep.cmd: In the Value Units field, the only value unit available is the % of Hard Limit.

substep.cmd: Click FileSave . The Save As window opens.
In the Specify Quota name field, type a name for the quota and click OK.

step.cmd: In the File Systems page of the Edit quota_name window, view the file systems to which the NetApp Quota applies.
In the Triggering Condition area, specify the event that triggers the constraint alert:

substep.cmd: In the Condition field, the default setting is User Consumes More Than n, where n represents a value that you define in the Value field. No other conditions are available.
In the Value field, type a numeric value that represents the amount of space a file must consume to violate the constraint.
In the Value Units field, select the unit of measurement. kilobytes, megabytes, or gigabytes.

step.info: Once Data Manager finds enough files that violate the condition (that exceed the total size amount you specified), the constraint is considered violated and the alert is triggered. When the alert is triggered, the actions that you specify in the Triggered Actions section are taken.

step.cmd: In the How often to run area, schedule how often you want to enforce the policy. You can choose from the following actions:

dlentry.dt: Enforce policy after every Probe or Scan
dlentry.dd: Enforce the policy after every probe or scan that is run against the selected file systems. If you want to automate file system extension, choose to apply the policy after every new probe or scan.
Enforce the policy immediately.

Check the quota one time at a specified time and date. You can use the drop-down lists to specify the month, day year, and the hour, minute, and AM/PM.The framework that starts the jobs finds all jobs in an interval between one minute to the scheduled time and the scheduled start time. This action ensures that if many jobs are planned to run at a certain time, they will not all start after the scheduled start time.

info.note: If the policy applies to multiple file systems and you select Run Now or Run Once at, messages specific to each file system are placed in the log file. Messages for multiple file systems can make it difficult to troubleshoot errors. To avoid this issue, you can select one policy at a time and then select Run Now.

step.cmd: In the Archive/Backup Options tab, select the type of the job and its TSM command options, if any.

dlentry.dd: Use this option to archive the files that violate a constraint. Archives are copies of data from online storage copies to auxiliary storage. Delete After Successful Archival Automatically delete the files that violated the constraint after they are successfully archived. See the IBM Tivoli Storage Manager Client User's Guide for more information about archives. administrators (Productivity Center Administrator role) can delete files even if they do not have the authority on the systems where the files are stored. This authority is provided by the agents, which run as root on UNIX systems or with administrator privileges on Windows computers.

Select this option to run a selective backup of the files that violate a constraint. You can back up specified files with a selective backup. These files are not excluded in the include-exclude list. They meet the requirement for serialization in the backup copy group of the management class that is assigned to each file. For more information about selective backups, see the IBM Tivoli Storage Manager Client User's Guide.

Select this option to run an incremental backup of the files that violate a constraint. You can do an incremental backup to back up new or changed files or directories from a client domain or from specified directories or files. These directories or files are not excluded in the include-exclude list. They meet the requirements for frequency, mode, and serialization as defined by a backup copy group of the management class that is assigned to each file. For more information about incremental backups, see the IBM Tivoli Storage Manager Client User's Guide.

Enter more command-line options in this field that is passed on to the dsmc command. You can enter up to 512 bytes of text. See the IBM Tivoli Storage Manager Client User's Guide for more information about valid command-line options.
